text: Heat Convection in Internal Flows 1 Some characteristics of thermally fully developed flows • The thermal boundary layer can be seen as barrier against the convective transfer of heat. • Along a thermally developing flow the convection coefficient drops significantly (why?). • However, we can show mathematically that in the fully developed region ℎ 𝑘 ≠ 𝑓(𝑥). • Hence, in the thermally fully developed flow of fluid with constant properties, the local convection coefficient is a constant, independent of x. Axial variation of convection heat transfer coefficient for flow in a tube. 2 A quick review of thermodynamics • Thermodynamics and heat transfer are highly complementary. • Many heat transfer problems do need a first law analysis. • First law of thermodynamics or balance of energy: The rate of increase in the amount of energy stored in a control volume must equal the rate at which energy enters the control volume, minus the rate at which energy leaves the control volume, plus the rate at which energy is generated within the control volume. • Mathematically: ∆ ሶ𝑬𝒔𝒕 = ሶ𝑬𝒊𝒏 − ሶ𝑬𝒐𝒖𝒕+ ሶ𝑬𝒈 ∆ ሶ𝑬𝒔𝒕: The rate of energy storage in the control volume ሶ𝑬𝒊𝒏 : The rate of energy transfer to the control volume ሶ𝑬𝒐𝒖𝒕: The rate of energy removal from the control volume ሶ𝑬𝒈: The rate of energy generated within the control volume 3 Conservation of energy in a control volume A quick review of thermodynamics, contd. • Energy can be carried to or from the control volume by: heat, work and mass flow. • For a steady state system, without internal energy generation (e.g. electrical resistance, exothermic chemical reactions): ሶ𝒎(𝒉 + 𝟏/𝟐𝑽𝟐+𝒈𝒛) 𝒊𝒏- ሶ𝒎(𝒉 + 𝟏/𝟐𝑽𝟐+𝒈𝒛) 𝒐𝒖𝒕+𝒒 − ሶ𝑾=0 ሶ𝑚 : mass flow rate (kg/s) h: specific enthalpy (J/kg) 1/2𝑉2+ 𝑔𝑧: specific kinetic and potential energies (J/kg) 𝑞 : net heat transfer rate to the control volume ሶ𝑊: net rate of work done by the control volume • If there is no work done and, the kinetic and potential energies are negligible and, the fluid is either a perfect gas or a liquid, then: 𝒒 = ሶ𝒎𝒄𝒑(𝑻𝒐𝒖𝒕 − 𝑻𝒊𝒏) • These conditions often hold in flow inside pipes and channels. 4 Energy balance • For flow of most fluids in a pipe 𝑞𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑣 = ሶ𝑚𝑐𝑝(𝑇𝑚,0 − 𝑇𝑚,𝑖) 𝑞𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑣: convective heat transfer rate (W/𝑚2) ሶ𝑚: mass flow rate of fluid (kg/𝑚3) 𝑐𝑝: specific heat capacity 𝑇𝑚,0 & 𝑇𝑚,𝑖: outlet and inlet mean temperatures of the fluid • This simple overall energy balance relates three important thermal variables (𝑞𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑣, 𝑇𝑚,0, 𝑇𝑚,𝑖).
